query: What was the estimated downtime in the original proposal Q-11876?
hypothesis: Gulfstream Customer Support Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0, dated June 2, 2023, is confirmed to exist and relates to a 192-Month Inspection with a standard work scope. It was provided to CITIOM in June 2023 and approved in September 2023. The request for the inspection that led to Proposal Q-11876 anticipated an estimated 'input' duration of 8-12 months. This duration significantly contradicts the previously speculated 35-45 days for downtime. The estimated cost of $800k, the specific mention of 'inspection work scope only', and the page number ('page 14') remain unconfirmed by these search results and require direct verification from the original proposal or detailed expert analysis.
final_output:
**MEMORANDUM**

**TO:** Senior Partner
**FROM:** [Your Name/Department]
**DATE:** October 26, 2023
**RE:** Analysis of Estimated Downtime in Gulfstream Customer Support Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0

---

## Executive Summary
Gulfstream Customer Support Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0, dated June 2, 2023, provided an estimated downtime of 35-45 business days for the 192-month inspection of G550 aircraft S/N 5174. This estimate was explicitly limited to the "Inspection only" work scope and did not account for time required to correct discrepancies discovered during the inspection. This figure is significantly lower than the historical downtime of 100-185 days for similar inspections conducted at the same Gulfstream facility.

## Factual Background
On June 2, 2023, Gulfstream issued Customer Support Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0 ("the Proposal") to CITIOM for a 192-month inspection of a G550 aircraft, S/N 5174. [WFW Restructured - D. Farnham Expert Report.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]; NO exhibits - CITIOM EXPERT REPORT - D. Farnham Expert Report - Mar 21 2025 copy.pdf, p. 5 [UNVERIFIED]]. The Proposal was prepared by Charles Philipp, Gulfstream's Service Center Coordinator at the time. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]].

The Proposal estimated a downtime of 35-45 business days to complete 2,800 labor hours for the inspection work scope. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]]. This estimate was located on page 14 of the document and was explicitly qualified as being for the "Inspection only." [EXPERT WITNESS REPORT March 5.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]; WFW Restructured - D. Farnham Expert Report.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]]. The Proposal contained further disclaimers, stating on page 8, item B, that "Any downtime estimates included in this proposal are based on Gulfstream’s 'general understanding' of the time required to accomplish the work outlined." [EXPERT WITNESS REPORT March 5.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]]. Additionally, the Proposal specified that the correction of any discrepancies found during the inspection was not included in the quoted price or timeline and would be addressed upon receiving customer approval. [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 2 [VERIFIED]].

Despite the 35-45 day estimate, historical records from Gulfstream's St. Louis facility—where the work was to be performed—showed that similar 192-month inspections typically required 100-185 days of downtime. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]; Craig Klebe Outline #1.docx, p. 4 [UNVERIFIED]]. The Proposal did not integrate any contingency for "over-and-above" scope. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]].

The Proposal was approved by AVCON JET in September 2023. [WFW Restructured - D. Farnham Expert Report.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]]. Subsequently, the project experienced significant delays. An email from Danny Farnham dated August 15, 2024, documents extreme dissatisfaction with project management, citing a lack of experienced technicians and stating that a "192 check" was taking an estimated 11 months. [111-206.pdf, p. 4 [UNVERIFIED]].

## Analysis

### Key Findings
- **The Proposal explicitly stated a downtime of 35-45 business days.** This figure is consistently referenced across multiple expert reports and legal documents as the basis of the client's initial expectations. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]; EXPERT WITNESS REPORT March 5.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]].
- **The downtime estimate was strictly limited to the inspection work scope.** Gulfstream's Prehearing Brief confirms that the Proposal clearly stated that the time and cost for correcting discrepancies were not included in the quote and required separate customer approval. [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 2 [VERIFIED]]. This qualification is a central element of Gulfstream's position.
- **The proposed downtime was substantially inconsistent with historical performance.** The 35-45 day estimate stands in stark contrast to the documented historical average of 100-185+ days for the same inspection at the same facility. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]]. This discrepancy forms the core of a potential claim for misrepresentation.
- **The actual project duration far exceeded the initial estimate.** Post-approval, the project encountered severe delays related to manpower and resource allocation, with the actual downtime extending towards 11 months, aligning more closely with the unstated historical averages than the Proposal's estimate. [111-206.pdf, p. 4 [UNVERIFIED]].

### Supporting Evidence
The strongest available evidence consists of verified statements from Gulfstream's own legal filings. The `Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf` confirms the Proposal's language excluding discrepancy correction from the quoted price and timeline. [Gulfstream - Prehearing Brief .pdf, p. 2 [VERIFIED]]. The `CITIOM Statement of Claim.pdf` corroborates the original estimate of 2,800 manhours. [CITIOM Statement of Claim.pdf, p. 3 [VERIFIED]].

The most direct evidence regarding the 35-45 day figure and its conflict with historical data comes from unverified documents, including the D. Farnham Expert Report and outlines for the cross-examination of Charles Philipp. These sources consistently cite the 35-45 day figure, its location on page 14 of the Proposal, the "inspection only" qualifier, and the contradictory 100-185 day historical average. [4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]; WFW Restructured - D. Farnham Expert Report.docx, p. 1 [UNVERIFIED]].

### Contradictions or Concerns
- **Estimate vs. Reality:** The primary conflict is the significant gap between the 35-45 day written estimate and the 100-185 day historical reality for such inspections at the St. Louis facility. It is a key concern whether providing such a low estimate without disclosing the historical data was misleading.
- **Working Hypothesis:** The Working Hypothesis notes an anticipated "input" duration of 8-12 months prior to the Proposal. The source for this anticipation is not identified in the evidence but, if substantiated, would be critical to understanding the client's state of mind and reliance on the subsequent 35-45 day quote.
- **Cost Discrepancy:** Reports cite conflicting cost estimates from the Proposal, with one mentioning $800k and others $600k, indicating potential reporting inconsistencies. [NO exhibits - CITIOM EXPERT REPORT - D. Farnham Expert Report - Mar 21 2025 copy.pdf, p. 7 [UNVERIFIED]].

### Evidence Strength Assessment
**Moderate.** The core facts are consistently asserted across multiple documents. The presence of verified legal briefs from both parties corroborates key structural elements of the dispute (e.g., the estimate's limited scope). However, the overall strength is constrained by the heavy reliance on unverified expert reports and litigation prep documents. Crucially, the primary source document—the Proposal itself—was not available for this analysis, preventing direct verification of its contents and context.

## Entities & Relationships
- **CITIOM:** The aircraft owner and client.
- **Gulfstream:** The service provider responsible for the aircraft inspection and author of the Proposal.
- **AVCON JET:** An agent for the client who formally approved the Proposal.
- **Charles Philipp:** The Gulfstream Service Center Coordinator who issued the Proposal.
- **Danny Farnham:** Appears to be an expert witness or representative for CITIOM, authoring an expert report and internal communications regarding project delays.

## Gaps & Limitations
- **Primary Document Unavailable:** The most significant limitation is the absence of the complete, verified Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0. Analysis is based entirely on excerpts and interpretations from secondary sources.
- **Unverified Sources:** The majority of citations refer to documents that could not be verified. The reliability of these excerpts is assumed but not confirmed.
- **Lack of Context:** Without the full Proposal and related correspondence, the context surrounding the 35-45 day estimate (e.g., discussions between the parties, specific client requests) is unknown. It is also unclear why new forecasting analytics available to Gulfstream in July 2023 were not used to revise the quote.

## Recommendations
1.  **Immediate Actions:**
    *   Prioritize obtaining a complete and certified copy of Gulfstream Customer Support Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0 and all related revisions and correspondence. This is essential for verifying all claims.

2.  **Additional Investigation Needed:**
    *   Depose Charles Philipp to ascertain the methodology used to arrive at the 35-45 day estimate, his awareness of the conflicting historical data at his own facility, and the decision-making process for excluding such data from the Proposal.
    *   Investigate the source of the "8-12 month" anticipated duration referenced in the Working Hypothesis to determine if it originated from Gulfstream or the client.
    *   Subpoena Gulfstream's internal records on historical downtime and man-hours for G550 192-month inspections at the St. Louis facility between 2018-2023.

3.  **Risk Mitigation Steps:**
    *   Develop a legal strategy focused on negligent misrepresentation, emphasizing the disparity between the estimate and known historical performance data.
    *   Prepare to counter Gulfstream's defense, which will center on the explicit "inspection only" language and disclaimers within the Proposal. The argument must demonstrate that these disclaimers do not absolve Gulfstream of the duty to provide an estimate that is reasonable and made in good faith.

Gulfstream admits that it performed maintenance and/or services for the Aircraft prior to the 192-month inspection, specifically the 144-month inspection between March and July 2020, and additional maintenance services in July and August 2023.

Gulfstream denies that it tracked and recorded labor hours and/or downtime specifically for 192-month inspections on G550 aircraft at its St. Louis facility since 2018. However, it admits to having systems to search for labor hours and visit length for maintenance service visits that may have included 192-month inspection tasks.

Gulfstream denies developing and implementing a new analytical tool in July 2023 designed to improve cost/downtime estimates for maintenance events like 192-month inspections. It admits to including estimates for additional downtime and costs for correcting discrepancies in maintenance proposals since July 2023, based on historical data.

Gulfstream denies that it did not disclose the existence or use of a 'New Analytical Tool' to Claimant or that it didn't use this tool to update the June 2023 Proposal. It admits it did not revise the June 2023 Proposal to include estimated downtime or costs for discrepancies discovered during the 192-month inspection.

Gulfstream denies outsourcing component evaluation, repair, and/or painting to its Savannah facility, but admits certain components (main entrance door, rudder, elevators) were sent to Savannah for these purposes.

Gulfstream denies that the transfer of components to its Savannah facility resulted in delays to the 192-month inspection or paint mismatch issues requiring rework on the main entrance door and rudder.

Gulfstream denies that it had opportunities to inspect for and identify corrosion during prior maintenance services (144-month inspection in 2020, July-August 2023 maintenance) where corrosion was later found during the 192-month inspection.

Gulfstream denies performing extensive repairs to the horizontal stabilizer due to significant internal corrosion during the 144-month inspection in 2020. It admits to performing repairs on the horizontal stabilizer due to internal bondline corrosion findings identified through non-destructive testing during the 144-month inspection and also admits to performing repairs on the horizontal stabilizer due to corrosion findings during the 192-month inspection.

Gulfstream denies that discrepancies and repairs during the 192-month inspection, related to conditions that existed or should have been addressed during prior maintenance services (including warranty), were Gulfstream's responsibility under warranties or standard of care.

Gulfstream denies having an auto-deletion policy of emails with no archival backup. It admits that its mail system automatically deletes emails after 60 days unless saved or archived by the user, pursuant to its corporate email retention policy.
Gulfstream provided a proposal to Claimant for a 192-month inspection.
The statement 'correction of discrepancies is not included in the quoted price' appears ten times in Section I of the proposal.
Section II of the proposal states that it 'does not include repairs to the Aircraft resulting from discrepancies . . . discovered during the [inspection]'.
Claimant retained Avcon Jet, A.G., to manage the aircraft and arrange for the maintenance visit.
Danny Farnham acted as Claimant's onsite representative during the visit.
Claimant argues that it is industry standard for repair stations to include cost and downtime estimates for repair work in connection with major structural inspections.
Gulfstream discovered significant corrosion on the Aircraft that far exceeded what was typically experienced on other G550 aircraft.
Gulfstream's 20-year structural warranty covered the costs associated with structural repairs.
Claimant's pre-hearing brief alleges spoliation of evidence and seeks an adverse inference.
Gulfstream has a document retention policy that provides for deletion of email messages after a certain time period unless archived.
Proposal #Q-11876 Rev 0 was issued in June 2023 and approved in September 2023.
The request for the inspection that led to Proposal Q-11876 anticipated an estimated 'input' duration of 8-12 months.

citations.text: June 2, 2023 Proposal Review: Gulfstream issued Customer Support Proposal #Q-11876
This is a "refresh" of the original letter that was sent in April to their Legal Counsel. Please make sure that the statements are accurate.

Over the last 6 months we have been told that everything possible was being done to hire, bring people from other facilities, other departments, etc, to augment the staffing of experienced technicians on our project. We, the owner of the aircraft and his representatives understood this to be a commi

How do you explain this dismal effort by Gulfstream management to meet the demands of ours and other projects in this hangar, in this facility? There are many words that could be used to describe this situation - I won't use them but I will and can say with confidence that this is the greatest examp
The proposal estimated 2,800 hours and 35–45 business days for a major 192-month G550 inspection.
Historical Gulfstream records showed downtime closer to 100–185 days at St. Louis.
You did not integrate over-and-above scope contingency into the quote.
Please find attached hereto, draft Purchase Agreement for the above-referenced Aircraft, for your review and approval.
We have inserted an estimate of the modification costs to be USD 70K. We trust that this is acceptable and as the LOI states, any surplus will be refunded back to the buyer.
However, as you may appreciate, the seller is hesitant to do so until the LOI is signed, and the deposit is in place.
Proposal Q-11876 for S/N 5174 (CIT00001–CIT00028).
The 35–45 working day estimate in Q-11876 did not include time for “over-and-above” work: Confirm omission of discrepancy estimates (CIT00001–CIT00028, esp. p. 14).
Ask if he knew St. Louis’s average downtime for G550 192-month checks was 100–185 days, not 35–45: Refer to GAC0052475–GAC0052752 data showing prior G550 inspections exceeding 100+ days routinely.

Please review the attached and provide any revisions and/or your approval. This is a "refresh" of the original letter that was sent in April to their Legal Counsel. Please make sure that the statements are accurate.
HI Murt and Michael, ... Once you are both okay with it, we will push through the rest of the approval process (Joe, Derek, etc) in an attempt to get to Mark by COB.
Please draft a response to his questions. Need to respond COB your time.
